title: Marco Polo
dialogue_triumphs: Susan: 'One day we'll know all the mysteries of the skies and we'll stop our wanderings.'
How Tegana should kill the Doctor: 'With a stake through the heart.'
The Doctor on having the TARDIS put in the stables: 'What does he think it is, a potting shed or something?'
At backgammon, amongst other wonderful wagers, the Doctor wins the 'total produce of Burma for one year'.
Khan explains to Ping-Cho: 'Your beloved husband-to-be, so anxious to be worthy of your love, drank a potion of quicksilver and sulphur, the elixir of life and eternal youth. And expired.'
goofs: William Hartnell has an odd hysterical fit in episode one, laughing his head off for a full minute at all the troubles that have befallen the travellers.
The caption slide at the end of episode two reads: 'Next Episode: The Cave of Five Hundred Eyes'.
In episode seven, Kublai Khan refers to backgammon as a game of cards.
The use of Peking is anachronistic (it should be Khan-balik).
In 1289, Polo was anxious to leave China against Kublai's wishes, so what's he doing on the Pamir Plateau?

continuity_notes.name: TARDIS
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's time machine and spaceship
continuity_notes.current_status: One burnt-out circuit deactivates the lights, water supply and heating. Condensation forms in the interior as it would inside any box in a hot climate.

continuity_notes.name: The Doctor
continuity_notes.description: The titular character of the series
continuity_notes.current_status: Can play backgammon well, but loses his bet with Kublai Khan over the TARDIS. Can horse-ride, but has back trouble as a result. Has problems with high altitudes and lack of water, and likes bean sprout soup.

continuity_notes.name: Ian
continuity_notes.current_status: Can ride, sword-fight, isn't very good at chess and knows lots of O' level science things, plus the fact that bamboo bangs in fire.

continuity_notes.name: Susan
continuity_notes.current_status: Uses words like 'fab' and is surprised by the idea of arranged marriages. She's had 'many homes in many places'.

roots: John Lucarotti's Canadian TV series about Polo
links: The Location of Gallifrey, 'Terror of the Autons'

locations.name: Peking
locations.current_status: Final destination of the journey in 1289

untold_adventures: Susan has seen the metal seas of Venus.
qv: The Location of Gallifrey, 'Terror of the Autons'
additional_notes: The device of Polo narrating map journey inserts is sweet, and the sheer length of time narrated makes this the longest 'real time' Who story.
bottom_line: Obviously wonderful, but a little too loose and unstructured to be the all-conquering classic of repute. Then again, we're denied the splendour of the costumes and sets.
